case_vignette: An African-American man, aged 35 years, presents with a 3-month history of pruritic penile lesions. Examination reveals an arcuate pattern of raised violaceous-to-flesh-colored papules with central clearing on the glans penis and a few scattered, raised violaceous-to-flesh-colored polygonal papules of the glans penis and distal penile shaft. Results of the remainder of the skin examination are normal, and there is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. His sexual history includes no previous sexually transmitted diseases and no new sexual partners within the past year.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing itchy spots on my private area for about three months.
How old are you?
I am 35 years old.
Have you noticed any rashes, blisters, or sores in the affected area?

Yes, I have noticed some raised, purplish to skin-colored bumps that form a ring-like pattern with some clearing in the middle, as well as a few raised, purplish to skin-colored bumps on the head and the lower part of my private area.
Do you have a history of similar symptoms or any other medical conditions?
No, I haven't had any previous sexually transmitted diseases or similar symptoms before.
Do you take any medications or have any known allergies?
The case vignette does not provide information about medications or allergies, so I can't speak to that.
Do you have a family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
The case vignette does not provide information about family history, so I can't speak to that.
**Final Diagnosis:** Tinea Cruris
